docs.lead_paragraph: Murray Nossel's warm and fuzzy documentary ''Paternal Instinct'' reminds you that parenthood is something not to be entered casually. For the movie's three immensely likable subjects, two gay men and a female surrogate, it is a sacred task. In 1994, when Mark, a software designer, and his partner of 10 years, Erik, a land conservationist, gazed into the future, they concluded that having one or two children would enrich and complete the next phase of their life together. Preferring not to adopt, they decided to find a surrogate to conceive a child through artificial insemination and placed an advertisement on the Internet.

headline.main: A Family Born of an Unusual Collaboration

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews documentary movie Paternal Instinct, directed by Murray Nossel (M)
docs.snippet: Murray Nossel's warm and fuzzy documentary is a portrait of two gay men and a female surrogate who join forces to create new life.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even after reducing its recruiting target for May, the Army missed it by about 25 percent, Army officials said on Tuesday. The shortfall would have been even bigger had the Army stuck to its original goal for the month. On Friday, the Army is expected to announce that it met only 75 percent of its recruiting goal for May, the fourth consecutive monthly shortfall in the number of new recruits sent to basic training. Just over 5,000 new recruits entered boot camp in May.

headline.main: After Lowering Goal, Army Falls Short on May Recruits

docs.abstract: Army missing its recruiting target for May by about 25 percent, fourth consecutive monthly shortfall; just over 5,000 new recruits enter boot camp for May; original target of 8,050 was cut early in month to 6,700; chart contrasts recruiting goals with actual recruits (M)
docs.snippet: Even after reducing its recruiting target for May, the Army still missed it by about 25 percent, Army officials said.

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT; Damien Cave contributed reporting from New York for this article
